title: Nashville shooter planned attack for months, says police
description: Authorities have not yet established a motive for the shooting that left six people dead, including three children.

title: Two civilians dead as Israel bombs Syria for fourth time in less than a week
description: Syria's state news agency says national air defense intercepted hostile targets over Damascus.

title: Nasa names crew for Artemis II lunar mission
description: The first moon crew in 50 years will be the first to fly NASA's Orion capsule, launching atop a Space Launch System rocket from Kennedy Space Center no earlier than late 2024

title: When Basquiat electrified Paris
description: In the 1980s, the French capital captivated the star of the American underground. This spring, he is showcased in two exhibitions, at the Fondation Louis Vuitton and the Philharmonie de Paris.

title: 'Succession': A little fatherly love and a lot of betrayal
description: 'Succession' final season (2/10). Every week, 'Le Monde' reviews the trials and tribulations of the Roy family and its media empire.

title: In the United States, 'zombie' companies eventually die
description: The end of free money is leading to a return to a market selection of companies and a logical rise in bankruptcies while some are trying last-chance rescues.

title: Spain and Portugal strengthen Iberian axis
description: While the two countries have long been at odds, their socialist prime ministers are coordinating closely to increase their influence in Brussels and invest in promising sectors.

title: Russia's invasion of Ukraine leaves EU's left fractured
description: Because of anti-militarism or a hatred of NATO, certain branches on the left or far left across Europe are hostile or reluctant to give military aid to Ukraine.

title: Moons around rogue planets may hold life, even without the sun
description: Finding water around rogue planets: it's a hypothesis that some French scientists are exploring to further our knowledge of the universe.

title: Jailed US reporter's defense appeals Russian arrest
description: 'Wall Street Journal' reporter Evan Gershkovich was arrested on espionage charges, the first time a US correspondent had been detained on spying accusations since the Cold War.

title: Finland to become 31st NATO member on Tuesday
description: Finland's foreign minister will hand over formal accession papers to US top diplomat Antony Blinken on Tuesday.

title: ChatGPT: 'A pause, if there is one, must be used to hold artificial intelligence players accountable'
description: Hundreds of experts and personalities are warning about the threat that AI is bringing to humanity. This awareness is a curious mixture of lucidity, false naivety and well-understood interests, writes Stéphane Lauer in his column.

title: French pension reform: This week's timeline
description: An 11th day of nationwide protests is due to take place this Thursday, after union representatives are to meet with Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne on Wednesday.

title: Vladlen Tatarsky, ultranationalist Russian blogger, killed in a Saint Petersburg cafe explosion
description: The military correspondent with ties to the Wagner Group was a strong supporter of the 'special operation' in Ukraine. A suspect was arrested Monday morning.

title: Paris 2024 Olympics: French Army worries about being called in to provide security
description: Due to a possible lack of private security personnel, resorting to the military is being considered. The army fears a surge in last-minute needs.

title: Hutchinson launches GOP 2024 bid, calls on Trump to drop out
description: Former Arkansa Governor Asa Hutchinson announced his candidacy on Sunday saying 'the office is more important than any individual person.'

title: French minister defends her 'Playboy' front cover appearance after backlash
description: 'Women are free,' said Marlène Schiappa, the junior minister for citizenship, who spoke to the magazine about women's rights and gay rights. The prime minister told her the move was 'not at all appropriate'.

title: Rental e-scooters banned from Paris, Mayor Hidalgo welcomes referendum win
description: Parisians voted against the renewal of their city's rental electric scooter contracts by 89.03%, though the turnout was very low (7.46%).

title: Ryuichi Sakamoto, composer and bridger between avant-garde and popular art, has died
description: A member of the electro-pop group Yellow Magic Orchestra, the Japanese musician was also the composer of the soundtracks for 'Furyo' and 'The Last Emperor,' for which he won an Oscar in 1988.

title: Finnish elections: Conservatives clinch win after economy-dominated campaign
description: The Social Democrats, led by Prime Minister Sanna Marin, are in third place, behind the conservative National Coalition Party (NCP) and the nationalist Finns Party.

title: Oil prices soar after OPEC announces shock output cut
description: Both main crude contracts jumped almost six percent at one point following the cut by Saudi Arabia, Iraq, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Algeria and Oman, which was the biggest since the group slashed two million barrels per day in October.

title: 'Are European leaders prepared to deal with the consequences of a possible regime change in Turkey?'
description: The potential election of Kemal Kiliçdaroglu could help to ease Turkish-European relations but could also create problems, says former EU ambassador to Turkey, Marc Pierini, in an article in 'Le Monde.'

title: Men are absent from the conversation on sexuality
description: Few male experts speak out on sexual or gender issues, writes our columnist Maïa, who deplores this under-representation: Society as a whole would benefit from free and informed male voices.

title: In Montenegro, President Milo Djukanovic suffers a resounding defeat after 30 years in power
description: 36-year-old economist Jakov Milatovic, winner of the presidential election, has promised to bring the country into the EU as soon as possible.
